N. Y.
Sophomores presented
a paradoxical welcome to the
Freshman class on the last day of
October. After the annual "ducking party" the Sophs suspended
hazing and entertained the first
year men at a smoker.
*
Penn State has a veteran rooter
who has followed the fortunes of
the Nittany Lions for 40 years.
He is Andy Lytle, over 80 years
old, who until three years ago
hadn't missed a Penn State game,
at home or away, since the first
State team journeyed to Lewisburg to play Bucknell in 1881.
For the past three years Andy
Lytle has been too weak to travel
but has witnessed every home
game.

PETERS, REIBLICH, YATES
SCORE IN INTRAMURAL
RIFLE MATCH
Schedule for Year Announced. Hopkins Joins Intercollegiate Ass'n.
11 Matches Scheduled

First, second and third prizes
for the winners of the first intramural match of the season held by
the Rifle Club last Friday went to
B. G. Peters, G. K. Reiblich, and
J. M. Yates, respectively. There
was plenty of competition for these
sharpshooters, for over 60 men
turned out for the match. Lieutenant Sherwood stated enthusiastically that the shooting was exceptionally good. Peters and Reiblich
scored 185, whereas Yates was
right on their heels with a score of
183.
"Proficiency in markmanship is
the object sought," Lieutenant Sherwood said. "Participation in these
intra-mural matches will give the
new men practice in shooting under match conditions, and will pave
the way for a successful season.
Prizes are offered - to give a man a
little steadier aim."
Second Match Today

The second day match of the intramural series will be held today
as usual in the north loft of Gilman Hall from 1 to 6 P. M. This
time, when the smoke has cleared
away, five prizes will be awarded.
Conditions of the match are as
follows:
Position: Kneeling; one target,
2 shots on each bull's-eye, including the sighting bull.
Eligibility: Open to all members
of the club.
Rifles: Any rifle, cal. 22.
Ammunition: Any cal. 22.
Prizes: First, $5.00; second,
$3.00; third, $2.00; fourth, $1.00;
fifth, 100 rounds of ammunition.
Team practice is held on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Fridays at
4 P. M.

REVERIES

THE NEWS-LETTER
MAILBAG

BY OLD ALUMNUS

All letters intended for publication
must be concise, written in ink on
regular letter size paper, on one side
only.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be
printed if request is made that they be
omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to
be taken as an indorsement of its views
by the "News-Letter," which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

Old Johnny Hopkins is nearing
its fiftieth anniversary. That
seems to be the keynote of the
greeting on every tongue as the
Old Alumnus meets occasional
fellow-alumni, particularly those
of the latter who live at a distance
from Baltimore. From the creeping, tottering, old-timer, who
speaks fondly of "Little RO3S
Street" to the most recent acquisition from the class of '24 who
looks with suspcion upon Phi
Beta Kappa comes the same sentiment that "something must be
done about it."
Strangest thing about it is that
the great bulk of enthusiasm is
not confined,to the ranks of the
boisterous A. B.'s but is shared
equally by the M. D.'s and Ph.
D.'s who owe a previous allegiance to a "first love." It would
prove interesting to hear from
some of them, I'm sure.
Saw old "Bill" Ross, A. B. '99,
just the other day. Bill is now a
very successful Chicago banker,
but he's still dead interested in
the old college. He has showed
that by his work in Pittsburgh,
Cleveland and Chicago, where he
brought into being Hopkins alumni associations. Founded within
the past two decades, they have
perhaps faded, as the demon organizer withdrew his enthusiastic
guidance to new fields. Bill is
now secretary of the association
in Chicago and is much in favor
of an anniversary celebration.

WE INSULT PLAYERS

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
The idea of applauding when
one of our football players is lying
on the ground suffering seems assinine to me. I have seen many
colleges play football games and
have been to many fields where
Hopkins teams have not been one
of the contenders, but never have
I seen any cheering section rise and
applaud when one of its classmates
was lying on the ground suffering.
When a man is in this condition h
is no time for applause, when he
has risen to his feet is the moment
to lend him a hand. When he is
on his back the best way to help
him get up is by remaining as quiet
as possible.
The idea of a cheer for him as
soon as he has been hurt would be
in order, but when it is seen that
he is definitely injured, clapping is
no way to help the man. I have
had many men visiting Hopkins
from other colleges who have had
the same idea on the subject, and
even some felt it an insult to applaud when their men were injured.
I wish to call this to the attention
of the cheer leaders and believe it
a subject fit for open discussion and
that a definite decision should be
arrived at.
Yours truly,

at home or away, since the first

but has witnessed every home
game.

PETERS, REIBLICH, YATES
SCORE IN INTRAMURAL
RIFLE MATCH
Schedule for Year Announced. Hopkins Joins Intercollegiate Ass'n.
11 Matches Scheduled

First, second and third prizes
for the winners of the first intramural match of the season held by
the Rifle Club last Friday went to
B. G. Peters, G. K. Reiblich, and
J. M. Yates, respectively. There
was plenty of competition for these
sharpshooters, for over 60 men
turned out for the match. Lieutenant Sherwood stated enthusiastically that the shooting was exceptionally good. Peters and Reiblich
scored 185, whereas Yates was
right on their heels with a score of
183.
"Proficiency in markmanship is
the object sought," Lieutenant Sherwood said. "Participation in these
intra-mural matches will give the
new men practice in shooting under match conditions, and will pave
the way for a successful season.
Prizes are offered - to give a man a
little steadier aim."
Second Match Today

The second day match of the intramural series will be held today
as usual in the north loft of Gilman Hall from 1 to 6 P. M. This
time, when the smoke has cleared
away, five prizes will be awarded.
Conditions of the match are as
follows:
Position: Kneeling; one target,
2 shots on each bull's-eye, including the sighting bull.
Eligibility: Open to all members
of the club.
Rifles: Any rifle, cal. 22.
Ammunition: Any cal. 22.
Prizes: First, $5.00; second,
$3.00; third, $2.00; fourth, $1.00;
fifth, 100 rounds of ammunition.
Team practice is held on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Fridays at
4 P. M.

All letters intended for publication

freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

Old Johnny Hopkins is nearing
its fiftieth anniversary. That
seems to be the keynote of the
greeting on every tongue as the
Old Alumnus meets occasional
fellow-alumni, particularly those
of the latter who live at a distance
from Baltimore. From the creeping, tottering, old-timer, who
speaks fondly of "Little RO3S
Street" to the most recent acquisition from the class of '24 who
looks with suspcion upon Phi
Beta Kappa comes the same sentiment that "something must be
done about it."
Strangest thing about it is that
the great bulk of enthusiasm is
not confined,to the ranks of the
boisterous A. B.'s but is shared
equally by the M. D.'s and Ph.
D.'s who owe a previous allegiance to a "first love." It would
prove interesting to hear from
some of them, I'm sure.
Saw old "Bill" Ross, A. B. '99,
just the other day. Bill is now a
very successful Chicago banker,
but he's still dead interested in
the old college. He has showed
that by his work in Pittsburgh,
Cleveland and Chicago, where he
brought into being Hopkins alumni associations. Founded within
the past two decades, they have
perhaps faded, as the demon organizer withdrew his enthusiastic
guidance to new fields. Bill is
now secretary of the association
in Chicago and is much in favor
of an anniversary celebration.

WE INSULT PLAYERS

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
The idea of applauding when
one of our football players is lying
on the ground suffering seems assinine to me. I have seen many
colleges play football games and
have been to many fields where
Hopkins teams have not been one
of the contenders, but never have
I seen any cheering section rise and
applaud when one of its classmates
was lying on the ground suffering.
When a man is in this condition h
is no time for applause, when he
has risen to his feet is the moment
to lend him a hand. When he is
on his back the best way to help
him get up is by remaining as quiet
as possible.
The idea of a cheer for him as
soon as he has been hurt would be
in order, but when it is seen that
he is definitely injured, clapping is
no way to help the man. I have
had many men visiting Hopkins
from other colleges who have had
the same idea on the subject, and
even some felt it an insult to applaud when their men were injured.
I wish to call this to the attention
of the cheer leaders and believe it
a subject fit for open discussion and
that a definite decision should be
arrived at.
Yours truly,
